domains.name: Gross Motor Development
domains.description: Gross motor skills involve large muscle movements like walking, running, jumping, and climbing. These skills are essential for physical independence, participation in sports and play, and overall health. Strong gross motor development supports balance, coordination, and body awareness, which are foundational for more complex physical activities and daily tasks.

tier1.question: Does your child ride a bicycle without training wheels?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Biking is a benchmark for balance and motor planning.

tier1.question: Can your child jump rope consistently?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Requires timing of upper and lower body.

tier1.question: Does your child catch a small ball thrown from a distance?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Tracking fast moving objects.

tier1.question: Can your child skip smoothly and alternate feet?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Skipping requires coordinating both sides of the body.

tier1.question: Does your child run and change direction quickly without falling?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Dynamic balance is key for sports and playground safety.

tier2.question: Can your child do a cartwheel or similar gymnastic move?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Advanced body control in space.

tier2.question: Does your child hop on one foot for 10 or more consecutive times?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Single-leg stability indicates core strength and balance control.

tier2.question: Can your child throw a ball overhand with accuracy to hit a target?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Refined throwing shows motor planning and visual-motor integration.

tier2.question: Does your child participate in organized sports or physical activities?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Participation reflects motor confidence and physical fitness.

tier2.question: Can your child walk on a balance beam or curb without stepping off?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Balance beam walking shows refined postural control.

tier1.question: Is your child's handwriting legible?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Legibility affects school performance.

tier1.question: Can your child cut out complex shapes correctly?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Precision cutting.

tier1.question: Does your child draw detailed pictures with background/foreground?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Spatial organization on paper.

tier1.question: Can your child use a keyboard or tablet with their fingers effectively?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Technology skills are increasingly important for school tasks.

tier1.question: Does your child write numbers and letters without reversals?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Letter formation accuracy impacts writing speed and clarity.

tier2.question: Can your child tie shoelaces securely?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Complex sequencing.

tier2.question: Does your child build detailed structures with small blocks or Legos?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Small piece manipulation shows finger strength and coordination.

tier2.question: Can your child use utensils properly without spilling often?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Utensil control reflects refined hand coordination for daily tasks.

tier2.question: Does your child fold paper neatly along lines for crafts or origami?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Folding requires both hands to work together with precision.

tier2.question: Can your child use a pencil sharpener or other small tools independently?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Using small tools shows fine motor strength and problem-solving.

domains.name: Speech & Language
domains.description: Speech and language development encompasses both the ability to produce clear sounds (speech) and to understand and use words meaningfully (language). Strong communication skills are fundamental for expressing needs, building relationships, learning in school, and participating fully in social situations. Delays in this area can impact all aspects of development.

tier1.question: Does your child have clear speech (sounds correct: r, l, s, th)?
tier1.whyWeAsk: All speech sounds should be mastered by age 8.

tier1.question: Can your child tell a complex story with detail?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Narrative skills support reading comprehension.

tier1.question: Does your child understand jokes and puns?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Metalinguistic awareness.

tier1.question: Can your child use proper grammar in sentences most of the time?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Grammar mastery reflects language maturity for this age.

tier1.question: Does your child ask questions to learn new information?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Question-asking shows curiosity and language as a tool for learning.

tier2.question: Does your child follow 3-4 step complex instructions?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Classroom instructions are often complex.

tier2.question: Can your child explain the rules of a game to someone else?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Explaining rules requires organized and clear communication.

tier2.question: Does your child use vocabulary appropriate for their age and grade level?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Vocabulary breadth predicts reading comprehension success.

tier2.question: Can your child retell events in proper sequence?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Sequencing is essential for storytelling and understanding cause and effect.

tier2.question: Does your child understand when someone is being sarcastic or teasing?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Understanding social language cues is important for peer interactions.

domains.name: Social & Emotional
domains.description: Social-emotional development includes the ability to understand and manage emotions, form positive relationships, and navigate social situations. These skills are critical for mental health, school readiness, and lifelong success. Children who develop strong social-emotional skills are better equipped to handle stress, resolve conflicts, and build meaningful connections with others.

tier1.question: Does your child have close friends and play well in groups?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Peer relationships are central.

tier1.question: Does your child handle losing a game without a major tantrum?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Sportsmanship reflects regulation.

tier1.question: Can your child describe their feelings and empathy for others?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Verbalizing emotion.

tier1.question: Does your child separate from you easily for school or activities?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Separation ease shows emotional security and confidence.

tier1.question: Can your child cooperate and take turns during group activities?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Cooperation is essential for classroom and play success.

tier2.question: Does your child negotiate conflict mostly without adult help?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Gaining independence in social solving.

tier2.question: Can your child understand another person's point of view?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Perspective-taking is key to empathy and social problem-solving.

tier2.question: Does your child show pride in accomplishments and effort?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Healthy self-esteem drives motivation and resilience.

tier2.question: Can your child calm themselves down after being upset?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Self-calming strategies indicate emotional maturity.

tier2.question: Does your child include others and show kindness to peers?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Kindness and inclusion reflect social awareness and empathy.

domains.name: Cognitive / Learning
domains.description: Cognitive development involves thinking, problem-solving, memory, and understanding concepts. These skills form the foundation for academic learning and everyday decision-making. Strong cognitive abilities help children make sense of their world, learn new information, and apply knowledge in different contexts.

tier1.question: Is your child reading simple books independently?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Reading is the key academic skill here.

tier1.question: Can your child do simple addition and subtraction?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Math foundation.

tier1.question: Does your child tell time (hour/half-hour)?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Understanding time measurement.

tier1.question: Can your child follow classroom routines and remember daily schedules?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Memory for routines supports independence in school settings.

tier1.question: Does your child solve simple problems on their own before asking for help?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Independent problem-solving shows cognitive flexibility and confidence.

tier2.question: Does your child understand money concepts (coins)?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Applicable math skills.

tier2.question: Can your child understand cause and effect relationships?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Causal reasoning underpins science learning and everyday understanding.

tier2.question: Does your child remember and follow multi-step directions?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Multi-step memory is critical for completing complex tasks.

tier2.question: Can your child categorize and sort objects by multiple attributes?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Classification skills support organizational thinking and math concepts.

tier2.question: Does your child understand basic concepts of measurement (longer, heavier)?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Measurement concepts build foundation for advanced math and science.

domains.name: Adaptive & Self-Care
domains.description: Adaptive skills are practical life skills needed for independence, including dressing, eating, toileting, and personal hygiene. Mastering these skills builds confidence, reduces dependence on caregivers, and is essential for success in school and community settings. These abilities reflect a child's growing autonomy and self-management.

tier1.question: Does your child bathe/shower with minimal help?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Growing self-care autonomy.

tier1.question: Does your child engage in simple chores (e.g., making bed)?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Contributing to household.

tier1.question: Can your child dress themselves completely including buttons and zippers?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Full dressing independence is expected by this age.

tier1.question: Does your child remember to brush teeth without being reminded?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Routine self-care shows developing responsibility and health awareness.

tier1.question: Can your child prepare simple snacks or drinks safely?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Basic food prep shows independence and safety awareness.

tier2.question: Can your child make a simple phone call?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Using technology/tools.

tier2.question: Does your child manage their school backpack and supplies?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Material organization reflects executive function and responsibility.

tier2.question: Can your child choose weather-appropriate clothing?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Appropriate clothing choice shows practical reasoning.

tier2.question: Does your child know their address and phone number?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Personal information knowledge is important for safety.

tier2.question: Can your child handle money in simple transactions?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Money handling connects math learning to real-world independence.

domains.name: Sensory Processing
domains.description: Sensory processing is how the brain receives and responds to information from the senses (touch, sound, sight, taste, smell, movement, body position). Difficulties in this area can affect attention, behavior, motor skills, and emotional regulation. Understanding a child's sensory needs helps create supportive environments for learning and development.

tier1.question: Can your child sit and focus on homework/schoolwork for 15-20 mins?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Sustained attention required for school.

tier1.question: Is your child organized with their belongings?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Organization starts to emerge.

tier1.question: Does your child tolerate typical classroom noise and activity levels?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Tolerating sensory input in busy environments is key for school participation.

tier1.question: Can your child transition between activities without becoming upset?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Smooth transitions show adaptability and emotional regulation.

tier1.question: Does your child notice when their hands or face are messy?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Sensory awareness supports self-care and hygiene habits.

tier2.question: Does your child avoid certain clothes or food textures still?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Sensory issues should decrease; persistence is noted.

tier2.question: Can your child work in different environments (quiet library, busy classroom)?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Adapting to different settings shows sensory flexibility.

tier2.question: Does your child seek or avoid movement more than other children?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Movement seeking or avoidance may indicate vestibular processing differences.

tier2.question: Can your child regulate their energy level throughout the day?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Energy regulation affects learning readiness and behavior.

tier2.question: Does your child respond appropriately to unexpected touch or sounds?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Appropriate responses to sensory surprises indicate balanced sensory processing.

domains.name: Vision & Hearing
domains.description: Vision and hearing are the primary channels through which children learn about their environment. Clear vision is essential for reading, writing, and visual-motor tasks, while good hearing is critical for language development and communication. Early detection of vision or hearing problems can prevent delays in other developmental areas.

tier1.question: Does your child read without losing place on the line?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Tracking requires oculomotor control.

tier1.question: Does your child seem to hear well in a noisy classroom?
tier1.whyWeAsk: filtering noise is key for school.

tier1.question: Can your child copy information from the board without difficulty?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Copying from board tests visual accommodation and tracking.

tier1.question: Does your child respond when called from another room?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Hearing at a distance is important for safety and communication.

tier1.question: Can your child see details in pictures and books clearly?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Clear near vision is essential for reading and schoolwork.

tier2.question: Does your child reverse letters while reading/writing often?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Reversals should disappear by age 8.

tier2.question: Can your child distinguish similar looking letters (b/d, p/q)?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Letter discrimination is critical for reading accuracy.

tier2.question: Does your child complain of headaches or eye strain after reading?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Eye strain may indicate vision problems affecting reading stamina.

tier2.question: Can your child hear whispered speech from across a room?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Soft sound detection tests hearing acuity.

tier2.question: Does your child turn their head to hear better or sit close to see?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Compensatory behaviors may signal vision or hearing concerns.
